choices.text:
### System:
You are an AI assistant that follows instruction extremely well. Help as much as you can.

### User:
Explain origin of standard gauge for railways

### Response:


The standard gauge was first used in England and Wales during the 1830s, when a group of railway companies decided to adopt a common width between their tracks. The choice of 4 feet 8 inches (1,422 mm) as the standard gauge was based on practical considerations such as ease of construction and interoperability with existing railways.
The decision quickly became widely adopted in other countries around the world, including those in Europe, North America, Australia, and parts of Asia. Today, most railway lines use a standard gauge width of 4 feet 8 inches (1,422 mm), making it one of the most common track gauges used globally.
